nodes.bodyText: the ID property of the secret is provided here so the user can keep track of the different secrets without handing over the actual values. I also thought the id property could be provided in the payload to a PUT request on the management API if the user need to update this specific secret. (without creating another one, or submitting all of the other credentials, but that is not implemented yet) .

nodes.bodyText:
Indeed, the pwd-plain  does not have any sense here. removed.
the id field still have a use IMHO. When the user set some credentials, he can "verify" they are in the registry with receiving an id for each password. I think if I don't know hono very well I would be confused if I received an empty secrets array after registering a hashed password. With the id field I know the password is there.

salt
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -27,8 +27,9 @@ title = "Release Notes"
 
 ### API Changes
 
- * The device registry credentials endpoint will no longer handout details for hashed-password secrets.
-   Each password is given an ID which is now returned by the device registry.
+ * The device registry credentials endpoint will no longer handout sensitive details for hashed-password secrets.
+   `pwd-hash`, `Salt` and `hash-function` are stored by the device registry but not returned to the user.

nodes.bodyText: Updated, thanks for catching this !

nodes.bodyText: How about renaming this to the more general FIELD_ID since it is not really secrets specific anyway and might be used for other entities as well. WDYT?
Why not. I updated the description so it doesn't lower the code readability.
what is the uniqueness scope of this ID? I assume it is just the containing Credentials instance, right? However, IMHO we should document this here.
I updated the description.
Can these IDs be assigned by a client, i.e. when registering the credentials? If so, do we check that the IDs are unique within the credentials?
does this actually add credentials or does it replace all existing credentials? IMHO it is the latter ...
